com.percussion.cms.objectstore
Class PSProcessorProxy

java.lang.Object
  com.percussion.cms.objectstore.PSProcessorProxy
Direct Known Subclasses:
PSActiveAssemblyProcessorProxy, PSComponentDefProcessorProxy, PSComponentProcessorProxy, PSRelationshipProcessorProxy
public abstract class PSProcessorProxy
extends Object

This class presents the interfaces supported by the processor classes, but doesn't actually perform any work. It has a configuration file that is read to find the appropriate processor given a component type. That processor is instantiated and is used to perform the heavy lifting. Once the processor type is known, the config is searched for associated properties for the supplied component and procesor. These properties are made available to the real processor. The default processors support web services and direct server access both locally and remotely.

See the config schema, sys_CmsProcessorConfig.xsd for details on the format of the configuration file.

To provide an idea of how it will work, let's look at what happens when an operation is performed on a remote client using web services, say creating a new instance of some type.

  1. A new instance of the object would be created locally using the standard technique (e.g., new PSFolder("foo")).
  2. The object would be manipulated until it reached the desired state.
  3. The object would then be passed to the save method of this class.
  4. The proxy would look up the real processor and pass it the properties from the config file, which would include the name of the web service to use.
  5. The real processor would call toXml on the component and pass this element as the document when making the web service request. This request would be received by the web services handler at the server.
  6. The handler would re-create the original object, passing the supplied xml to the component's fromXml method.
  7. This object would then be passed to the local proxy processor's save method.
  8. The local proxy would look up the real processor and pass the config information. By default this processor will generate a new key and call toDbXml on the component and pass the generated fragment to the resource defined in the processor's config
  9. After this is successful, setPersisted is called on the component.
  10. Success is returned to the web service caller.
  11. The WS processor will call setPersisted on the remote object.
When the methods of a processor are called, a component type must be supplied (or it is obtained from the supplied component). In general, this should be the base name of the component (but for the relationship processor methods, it is an arbitrary name, usually based on the type of relationship being processed). This name is used to find the 'real' processor class name and a set of properties appropriate for this type of component. Most components will use the generic processor, which performs an internal request to a resource as described above.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Paul Howard

Field Detail

PROCTYPE_WEBSERVICE

public static final String PROCTYPE_WEBSERVICE
Processors are associated with component types by a type (or category) name. The types correspond generically to how the processor accomplishes its work. These are the defaults, any other arbitrary name is allowed. Not every component type is necessarily supported by every processor type. Processor types are case-insensitive.

This type of processor should be used on remote clients if you want to interface to the server with Web Services.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

PROCTYPE_REMOTE

public static final String PROCTYPE_REMOTE
See PROCTYPE_WEBSERVICE for more details.

This type of processor should be used on remote clients for direct access to support apps. It is nearly identical to the PROCTYPE_SERVERLOCAL, except it makes http requests rather than internal requests.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

PROCTYPE_SERVERLOCAL

public static final String PROCTYPE_SERVERLOCAL
See PROCTYPE_WEBSERVICE for more4 details.

This type of processor should be used when operating in the same VM as the Rhythmyx server. It uses internal requests to accomplish its work.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

RELATIONSHIP_COMPTYPE

public static final String RELATIONSHIP_COMPTYPE
The component type for relationship type operations, such as getChildren(), getParents() for a specified relationship.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

m_processorConfig

protected PSProcessorProxy.ProcessorConfig m_processorConfig
null until the first component entry is found in the config, then never null after that. After ctor is finished, never changes after that.

m_context

protected Object m_context
Passed to the processor when the various proxy methods are called. Set by the setProcessorContext method. May be null. What and whether this is needed is defined by the processors.

Constructor Detail

PSProcessorProxy

public PSProcessorProxy(String type,
                        Object ctx)
                 throws PSCmsException
Creates a proxy for a specific type of processor. The config file is obtained from the default location (in the jar containing this class). It is assumed the file name is CmsProcessorConfig.xml.

Parameters:
type - The type of processor for which this class is acting as a proxy. This is a general category such as "webservice", "remote" or "local". Several predefined ones are included with the PROCTYPE_xxx constants. See the config file for all possibilities. Never empty or null. This name will be used to find the processor's entry in the config document when the methods of this class are called.
ctx - A context object appropriate for the processor type, may be null if the processor does not require one.
Throws:
PSCmsException - for all errors constucting this processor.

PSProcessorProxy

public PSProcessorProxy(Reader configXml,
                        String type)
                 throws IOException
Creates a proxy for a specific type of processor.

Parameters:
configXml - The source containing the configuration file for the processors. The content must conform to the sys_CmsProcessorConfig schema. Never null. Takes ownership and closes the stream when finished.
type - The type of processor for which this class is acting as a proxy. This is a general category such as "webservice", "remote" or "local". Several predefined ones are included with the PROCTYPE_xxx constants. See the config file for all possibilities. Never empty or null. This name will be used to find the processor's entry in the config document when the methods of this class are called.
Throws:
IOException - If any problems occur reading data from the config.
Method Detail

setProcessorContext

public void setProcessorContext(Object ctx)
Each processor has a specified context which is required for the processor to perform the requested operations. The supplied object must match the type required by the processor type specified in the ctor. If one is required and not supplied, all requests will fail.

This method may need to be called more than once during the life of the proxy, see the description for the processor type for details.

Each time this method is called, a new processor will be instantiated, otherwise, each instantiated processor is cached and reused across multiple operations.

Parameters:
ctx - An object appropriate for the processor type. May be null if the processor does not require one.

createComponentProcessorGroups

protected Map createComponentProcessorGroups(IPSDbComponent[] components)
                                      throws PSCmsException
Looks up the processor for every supplied component and creates a collection for those that have the same processor.

Parameters:
components - Assumed not null and that no entries are null.
Returns:
Never null. Each entry has a processor as the key and a Collection as the value. The collection contains all the components in the supplied array that use that processor.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If the processor cannot be found or instantiated for any of the components.

assignKey

public void assignKey(IPSDbComponent[] comps,
                      PSKey parentKey)
               throws PSCmsException
For every component in the supplied array that has an unassigned key, the key is assigned. This is equivalent to what a processor will do when it is saving a component with an unassigned key.

This method is not supported by all processors.

Parameters:
comps - Never null and no entry can be null.
parentKey - If the supplied components are children of another component, then the key of the parent must be supplied. If supplied, it must be assigned.
Throws:
PSCmsException - If any errors occur while allocating the ids.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the processor can't fulfill the request.
